facts.text: Appeals arise from judgment and order dated September 20, 1967 of Delhi High Court in Income-tax Reference Nos. 2 and 3 of 1967.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Hegde, J.

facts.text: Relevant assessment years are 1952-53, 1955-56 and 1956-57.

anchor.surface_text: the companycerned assess- ment years are 1952-53, 1955-56 and 1956-57, the relevant accounting

facts.text: Relevant accounting periods are financial years ending March 31, 1952, March 31, 1955 and March 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: ment years are 1952-53, 1955-56 and 1956-57, the relevant accounting periods being financial years ending March 31, 1952, March 31, 1955 and March 31, 1956.

facts.text: Assessee is a registered firm deriving income from interest on securities, property, business and other sources.

anchor.surface_text: The assesses is a registered firm deriving income from interest on securities, property, business and other sources.

facts.text: Assessee purchased Nedous Hotel in Lahore sometime in 1946 for Rs 46 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime In the year 1946 it purchased the Nedous Hotel in Lahore for a sum of Rs 46 lakhs.

facts.text: Assessee raised loan of Rs. 30 lakhs from M/s. Bharat Bank Ltd., Lahore for purchase.

anchor.surface_text: For that purpose it raised a loan of Rs. 30 lakhs from M s. Bharat Bank Ltd., Lahore and a loan of Rs. 18 lakhs

facts.text: Assessee raised loan of Rs. 18 lakhs from the Raja of Jubbal for purchase.

anchor.surface_text: from M s. Bharat Bank Ltd., Lahore and a loan of Rs. 18 lakhs from the Raja of Jubbal.

facts.text: Assessee partly repaid the loan from Bharat Bank.

anchor.surface_text: The loan taken from the bank was partly repaid but as regards the loan

facts.text: Assessee agreed with Raja of Jubbal under which Raja accepted half share in property in lieu of loan and 1/3rd of outstanding bank liability, effective November 1, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: the assessee came to an agreement with the Raja under which the Raja accepted a half share in the said property in lieu of the loan advanced and also 1/3rd of the outstanding liability of the bank. This arrangement came into effect on November 1, 1951.

facts.text: After creation of Pakistan, Nedous Hotel declared evacuee property and vested in Custodian in Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: After the creation of Pakistan, declared an evacuee property and companysequently vested in the Custodian in the Pakistan.

facts.text: In returns for relevant years, assessee claimed losses of Rs. 1,00,723 for 1952-53, Rs. 1,16,599 for 1955-56 and Rs. 1,16,599 for 1956-57 on account of interest payable to bank, with gross annual letting value Nil.

anchor.surface_text: In its return for the relevant assessment years, the assessee claimed losses of Rs. 1,00,723.- Rs. 1,16,599/- and Rs. 1,16,599/- respectively but showed the gross annual letting. value from the said property at Nil. The loss claimed was stated to be on account of interest payable to the bank.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer held no income or loss from property can be considered as vested in Custodian, disallowed interest claim.

anchor.surface_text: Since the property in question has vested in the Custodian of Evacuee Property, in Pakistan, the Income-tax Officer held that numberincome or loss from that property can be companysidered in the assessees case. He accordingly disallowed the assessees claim in respect of the interest paid to the bank.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed ITO order.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner- companyfirmed the order of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Tribunal held assessee continued to be owner for computation of loss, interest deductible under s.9(1)(iv), relied on its decision for 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: In second appeal the Tribunal came to the companyclusion that the assessee still companytinued to be the owner of the property for the purpose of companyputation of loss. The Tribunal held that the interest paid is a deductable allowance under s. 9 1  iv  of the Act. In arriving it that companyclusion, the Tribunal relied on its earlier decision in the case of the assessee in respect of the assessment year 1951-52.

facts.text: At instance of assessee, Tribunal submitted question to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: thereafter at the instance of the assessee, the Tribunal submitted the question set out earlier.

facts.text: Full Bench of Delhi High Court (S.K. Kapur J) held assessee not owner for s.9.

anchor.surface_text: A Full Bench of the Delhi High Court speaking through S. K. Kapur, J. answered that question in the negative.

facts.text: Petitioner contended assessee continued owner with ultimate right to property for s.9.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged by Mr. V. C. Mahajan, learned Counsel for the assessee that the High Court erred in opining that the assessee was number the owner of the property, for the purpose of s. 9 of the Act. According to him the property vested in the Custodian only for the purpose of administration and the assessee still companytinued to be its owner.

facts.text: Respondent contended owner for s.9 is person entitled to income, legal owner not beneficial interest.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, it was companytended on behalf of the Revenue that the Incometax is companycerned with income, gains and profits. Therefore for the purpose of that Act, the owner is that person who is entitled to the income. According to the Revenue the word owner in s. 9 refers to the legal ownership and number to any beneficial interest in the property.

facts.text: Supreme Court held assessee was not owner of Nedous Hotel for purpose of s.9 during relevant years.

anchor.surface_text: After giving our careful companysideration to the question of law under companysideration, we have companye to the companyclusion that the  1  16, I.T.R. 123.  2  28, I.T.R. 510. assessee was number the owner of Neadous Hotel during the relevant assessment years for the purpose of s. 9 of the Act.

facts.text: Appeals dismissed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Hence these appeals fail and they are dismissed.

arguments.court_reasoning: Custodian is legal owner with all powers

arguments.claim: all evacuee property vests in Custodian under s.6(1) who has powers to take possession (s.9), receive payments (s.11), exempt from process (s.12), allot (s.14), invalidate transfers (s.16), restore (s.19), manage/sell/demolish (s.20), maintain accounts (s.22)

anchor.surface_text: For deciding the question whether the assessee was the owner of the property for the purpose of S. 9 of the Act during the relevant accounting years, we have to look to the provisions of the Ordinance. Let us first take a survey of the relevant provisions of the Ordinance and thereafter analyse the effect of those provisions. ... Section 22 1  requires the Custodian to maintain separate account of the property of each evacuee of which he has taken possession and shall cause to be made therein entries of all receipts and expenditure in respect therof.

arguments.claim: evacuee cannot exercise ownership rights (possess, lease, sell, mortgage, realize income) without Custodian consent; Custodian can; thus Custodian legal owner, evacuee has beneficial interest

anchor.surface_text: The Ordinance starts by saying that it is an Ordinance to provide for the administration of evacuee property and not management of evacuee property. The expression administration in relation to an estate, in law means managements and settling of that estate. ... The evacuee could not exercise any rights in that property except with the consent of the Custodian. He merely had some beneficial. interest in that property. No doubt that residual interest in a sense is ownership. The property having vested in the Custodian, who bad all the powers of the owner, he was the legal owner or the property. In the eye of the law, the Custodian was the owner of that property.

arguments.claim: under s.9 owner is person who can exercise rights of owner in own right, entitled to income; property cannot be owned by two with exclusive rights

anchor.surface_text: Section 9 1  says The tax shall be payable by an assessee under the head Income from Property ... of which he is the owner ... The question is who is the owner referred to in this section ? Is it the person in, whom the property vests or is it he who is entitled to some beneficial interest in the property It must be remembered that S. 9 brings to tax the income from property and not the interest of a person in the property. A property cannot be owned by two persons, each one having independent and exclusive right over it. Hence for the purpose of s. 9, the owner must be that person who can exercise the rights of the owner, not on behalf of the owner but in his own right.

arguments.claim: equitable considerations aside, interpreting evacuees as owners would require tax on unrealized income, contrary to reasonable interpretation

anchor.surface_text: For a minute, let us look at things from the practical point of view. If the thousands of evacuees who left practically all their properties as well as business in Pakistan had been considered as the owners, of those properties and business as long as the Ordinance was in force then those unfortunate persons would have had to pay income-tax on the basis of the annual letting value of their properties and on the income, gains and profits of the businesses left by them in Pakistan though they did not get a paisa out of those properties and businesses. Fortunately no one in the past interpreted the law in the manner Mr. Mahajan wants us to interpret. It is true that equitable considerations are irrelevant in interpreting tax laws. But these laws, like all other laws have to be interpreted reasonably and in consonance with justice.

arguments.claim: Official Assignee is owner under s.9 upon vesting per Presidency Towns Insolvency Act s.17, analogous to Custodian

anchor.surface_text: The question as to who is the owner of a house property under s. 9 of the Act in circumstances similar to those before us came up for consideration before the Calcutta High Court in the matter of The Official Assignee for Bengal  Estate of Jnanendra Nath Pramanik   1 . ... Section 17 of the, Presidency Towns Insolvency Act, reads On the making of an order of adjudication, the property of the insolvent wherever situate shall vest in the official assignee ... We may note that the powers of the Custodian are not less than that of the Official Assignee under the Presidency Towns Insolvency Act, 1909.

arguments.claim: in Official Assignee case, no beneficial qualifier to ownership; vesting makes Assignee owner for s.9

anchor.surface_text: Delivering the judgment of the Court in the Official Assignees case 1 , Costello, J. observed With regard to the first point, Mr. Page argued that although by section 17 of the Presidency Towns Insolvency Act these properties vested in the Official Assignee he did not thereby or thereupon become the owner of those properties within the meaning properly ascribable to that word for the purposes of the applicability of Section 9.

arguments.claim: Fleming case: income from sequestrated estate is trustee's, not insolvent's; test is entitlement to income

anchor.surface_text: The learned judges of the Calcutta High Court in reaching that conclusion relied on the decision in The Commissioner of Inland Revenue Fleming 1 . ... For determining the person liable to pay tax, the test laid down by the court was to find out the person entitled to that income.

arguments.claim: Fleming distinguishable because English statute liability not on owner of property

anchor.surface_text: An attempt was made by Mr. Mahajan to distinguish this case on the ground that under the corresponding English statute the liability to tax in respect of income from property is not laid on the owner of the property. It is true that s. 82 of the English Income- tax Act, 1952 is worded differently.

arguments.court_reasoning: principles underlying the two statutes are identical

arguments.claim: despite Custodian powers, evacuee continues as owner per observations in Amar Singh v. Custodian

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Mahajan contended that despite the fact that evacuee property was taken over by the Custodian and that he had been conferred with large powers to deal with it, an evacuee from Pakistan who owned that property before he migrated to India still continued to be the owner of the property. For this contention of his he placed reliance on some of the observations of this Court in Amar Singh v. Custodian, Evacuee Property, Punjab 1 .

arguments.court_reasoning: observations in context of Art.19(1)(f); residual right not ownership for s.9 which focuses on income receipt

arguments.claim: ownership is residue of all powers of use and disposal even if immediate control elsewhere per Pollock

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Mahajan next invited our attention to the observations in Pollock on Jurisprudence  6th Edn. 1929  178-80 Ownership may be described as the entirety of the powers of use and disposal allowed by law The owner of a thing is not necessarily the person who at a given time has the whole power of use and disposal very often there is no such person.

holdings.text: the assessee was not the owner of Nedous Hotel during the relevant assessment years for the purpose of s. 9 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: After giving our careful consideration to the question of law under consideration, we have come to the conclusion that the assessee was not the owner of Nedous Hotel during the relevant assessment years for the purpose of s. 9 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Property vested in Custodian under Pakistan Ordinance with full ownership powers (ss.6,9,11,12,16,19,20); assessee has only beneficial interest; owner under s.9 exercises rights in own right and entitled to income; analogies to Official Assignee vesting

holdings.text: for the purpose of s. 9, the owner must be that person who can exercise the rights of the owner, not on behalf of the owner but in his own right

anchor.surface_text: Hence for the purpose of s. 9, the owner must be that person who can exercise the rights of the owner, not on behalf of the owner but in his own right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.9 taxes income from property owned by assessee; property cannot have two owners with exclusive rights; focuses on entitlement to income and exercise of ownership rights

holdings.text: The property having vested in the Custodian, who had all the powers of the owner, he was the legal owner of the property. In the eye of the law, the Custodian was the owner of that property.

anchor.surface_text: The property having vested in the Custodian, who had all the powers of the owner, he was the legal owner of the property. In the eye of the law, the Custodian was the owner of that property.

holdings.text: Official Assignee is the owner of the property under s.9 upon vesting under Presidency Towns Insolvency Act s.17

anchor.surface_text: the Official Assignee was the owner of the property and he could rightly be assessed in respect of the income from that property under s. 9.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Vesting transfers ownership for tax purposes; powers analogous to Custodian; supported by precedent

precedents.citation: The Official Assignee for Bengal Estate of Jnanendra Nath Pramanik 1 5. I.T.R. 233.

anchor.surface_text: The Official Assignee for Bengal Estate of Jnanendra Nath Pramanik 1 5. I.T.R. 233. could be taxed in respect of the income of the property under s. 9. The High Court held that the property did not by reason of the adjudication of the debtor cease to be a subject fit for taxation and in view of the provisions of s. 17 of the Presidency Towns Insolvency Act, the Official Assignee was the, owner of the property and he could rightly be assessed in respect of the income from that property under s. 9.

precedents.case_name: Official Assignee for Bengal Estate of Jnanendra Nath Pramanik
precedents.cited_proposition: Official Assignee vested with insolvent's property under Presidency Towns Insolvency Act is the owner of the property for purposes of s. 9 of Income-tax Act and liable to tax on income from property
precedents.cited_holding: the Official Assignee was the owner of the property and he could rightly be assessed in respect of the income from that property under s. 9

precedents.citation: Sir Currimbhoy Ebrahim Baronetcy Trust v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 612 I.A. 1209

anchor.surface_text: Sir Currimbhoy Ebrahim Baro- 1  5 I.T.R. 233. netcy Trust v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 612 I.A. 1209  is of assistance. At page 217 Sir Sydney Rowlatt when giving the judgment of the Privy Council made this observation In their Lordships opinion the effect of the Act creating these trusts is not to give the baronet for the time being any right to any part of the interest or property specifically or any right which, even granting that the legal title is not the only thing that can ever be looked at, would make it true to say that any proportion of the interest is not receivable or any proportion of the property is not owned by the incorporated trustees.

precedents.case_name: Sir Currimbhoy Ebrahim Baronetcy Trust v Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: No difference between legal estate and equitable estate in this country
precedents.cited_holding: granting that the legal title is not the only thing that can ever be looked at

precedents.citation: The Commissioner of Inland Revenue Fleming 1 14, Tax Cases 78.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Inland Revenue Fleming 1 . That appeal related to a claim for repayment of income-tax to which the respondent claimed to be entitled in respect of personal allowance introduced into the Income-tax system by S. 18 of the Finance Act, 1920. The claim arose in the following circumstances The respondent was declared insolvent in 1921. He was then the owner of heritable properties. His insolvency lasted till May 10, 1926.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Inland Revenue v Fleming
precedents.cited_proposition: During insolvency, income from vested properties is income of the trustee, not the insolvent
precedents.cited_holding: Any income that did arise from those estates was income of the trustee as such, and he and he alone had the right to put it into his pocket as income

precedents.citation: Trustees of Sir Currimbhoy Ibrahim Baronetcy Trust v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 2 2 I. T.R. 148.

anchor.surface_text: Trustees of Sir Currimbhoy Ibrahim Baronetcy Trust v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 2 . The Counsel for the appellant was unable to point out to us any decision which has taken a view contrary to that taken in Official Assignees case 3 .

precedents.case_name: Trustees of Sir Currimbhoy Ibrahim Baronetcy Trust v Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Conclusion in Official Assignee case receives support from this Privy Council decision

precedents.citation: Amar Singh v. Custodian, Evacuee Property, Punjab 1 1957 S.C.R.

anchor.surface_text: Amar Singh v. Custodian, Evacuee Property, Punjab 1 . Therein delivering judgment of the Court Jagannadhadas, J. observed  at p. 815 of the report 1 5 I.T.R. 233.  2 2 I. T.R. 148.  3  1957 S.C.R. Stopping here it will be seen that the position, in its general aspect, is that all evacuee property is vested in the Custodian. But the evacuee has not lost his ownership in it.

precedents.case_name: Amar Singh v Custodian Evacuee Property Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Evacuee has not lost ownership in vested evacuee property; retains ultimate ownership subject to limitations
precedents.cited_holding: the evacuee has not lost his ownership in it. The law recognised his ultimate ownership subject to certain limitations

precedents.citation: Raja P. Lal Choudhary v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1 16, I.T.R. 123.

anchor.surface_text: Raja P. Lal Choudhary v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1 . Therein the question was whether the receiver of a property appointed by court was the owner of the property for the purpose of s. 9 of the Act. The court came to the conclusion that he was not the owner as the property did not vest in him.

precedents.case_name: Raja P Lal Choudhary v Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: Receiver appointed by court is not owner under s.9 as property does not vest in receiver
precedents.cited_holding: he was not the owner as the property did not vest in him

precedents.citation: Nawah Bahadur of Murshidabad v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal 2 28, I.T.R. 510.

anchor.surface_text: Nawah Bahadur of Murshidabad v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal 2 . The facts of that case were Properties which belonged to the ancestors of the Nawab of Murshidabad as Rulers, were, some time after the territories had been conquered by the British, settled by the Secretary of State for India in the year 1891 on the then Nawab of Murshidabad under a deed of settlement which provided that such properties shall henceforth and for ever be held and enjoyed by the said Nawab Bahadur and such one among his lineal male heirs as may be successively entitled to hold the said title in perpetuity,.

precedents.case_name: Nawab Bahadur of Murshidabad v Commissioner of Income-tax West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Nawab is owner under s.9 despite restrictions on alienation; liable to tax on full income
precedents.cited_holding: the Nawab for the time being was the owner of such properties for the purposes of s. 9 of the Act and the Nawab was therefore liable to be assessed to income-tax on the income of such properties
